Fig. 1 SEM micrographs of the TiO2 nanotubes before (left) and after (right) vanadia CVD deposition. Side (top) and cross section (bottom) views. Fig. 2 X-ray diffractograms obtained on the TiO2 nanotube arrays before (bottom) and after CVD of VO x (top). Labels indicate peaks for anatase (A), rutile (R) and titanium (T). Fig. 3 Top: Raman spectrum for the VO x coated TiO2 nanotube array. Bottom: Raman spectrum obtained on the TiO2 nanotube array before vanadia deposition. Fig. 4 XPS O 1s and V 2p spectra of the TiO2 nanotube array after VO x deposition. The spectra were fitted using Gaussian–Lorentizian functions to resolve the individual 1s contributions of oxygen and the 2p1/2 and 2p3/2 contributions of V+5 and V+4 species. Fig. 5 Catalytic activity data of the VO x coated TiO2 nanotube array. Left vertical axis: fractional conversion of ethanol (▴). Right vertical axis selectivities to acetaldehyde (●) and ethylene (○) as a function of time on stream using different weight hourly space velocities (WHSV); WHSV1=10,637 (mol ethanol/molVh−1); WHSV2=15,955 (mol ethanol/molVh−1); WHSV3=42,546 (mol ethanol/molVh−1). Fig. 6 Ethanol partial oxidation rates as function of fractional conversion for the VO x coated TiO2 array. [43] 0.6 ∼4×10−3 s−1 VO x /TiO2–SiO2 Lakshmi et al. [46] 2.3 ∼7×10−3 s−1 A novel nanoengineered VO x catalyst supported on highly ordered TiO2 nanotube arrays for partial oxidation reactions Jose E. Herrera ⁎ Tayirjan T. Isimjan Inusa Abdullahi Ajay Ray Sohrab Rohani Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering, The University of Western Ontario, London, Ontario, N6A 5B9, Canada ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +1 519 661 2111x81262; fax: +1 519 661 3498. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Nanoengineered VO x on a highly ordered TiO2 nanotube prepared through CVD. ► Highly dispersed vanadia phase present on the surface of the TiO2 nanotube array. ► Ethanol partial oxidation used to evaluate the catalytic activity of this material. A new class of nanoengineered partial oxidation catalyst has been prepared through the use of chemical vapor deposition of a vanadium oxide precursor over a highly ordered TiO2 nanotube array. A battery of characterization techniques including X-ray diffraction (XRD) together with scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Raman, and DRS-UV/vis indicate that the vanadia species are extremely well dispersed onto the surface of the nanotube array. Studies of the catalytic activity of this material were performed using the partial oxidation of ethanol as a probe reaction and compared with those obtained using typical P-25 TiO2 powdered support. Results showed that the nanoengineered approach to catalyst fabrication leads to a highly active catalytic material where most of the vanadium oxide phase is located on the surface and accessible for catalysis. Keywords Vanadium oxide Partial oxidation Ethanol TiO2 nanotubes UV–vis XRD XPS Raman SEM 1 Introduction Catalytic systems based on vanadium oxides are known to be highly active and selective for a number of industrially relevant chemical transformations. It has already been established that the catalyst support plays an important role in both the activity and selectivity [1–4]. Several particle supported V2O5 catalyst formulations have been tested in important industrial scale processes such as selective oxidation [5–7], ammoxidation of hydrocarbons [8], and selective reduction of NO x with NH3 in the presence of O2 [9]. Al2O3, SiO2, TiO2 and ZrO2 nanoparticles are commonly used as supports for these catalysts [6,7,10–12]. Among these, titanium oxide, leads to an enhancement of the catalytic properties of vanadium oxide [13–16]. However, variations on the available surface area of TiO2 powder supports present challenges for a uniform surface coverage of vanadium oxide and creates disadvantages in terms of availability of active sites to the reactants [17]. In this contribution, we present an alternative to conventional systems for the specific case of partial oxidation process over VO x /TiO2 catalysts. This novel methodology is based on the use of a flat substrate of highly ordered TiO2 nanotube arrays as support for vanadium oxide. Due to its highly ordered vertical orientation this material presents advantages over conventional VO x /TiO2 systems such an availability of accessible surface area for catalysis and a potentially uniform coverage of VO x catalytic species on the surface support achieved under the right VO x deposition conditions. In combination with a vanadia chemical vapor deposition this approach leads to the fabrication of a highly active thin layer of vanadium oxide anchored on titanium oxide nanotubes which are in turn anchored to a titanium flat surface. The use of a titanium flat surface is an attractive alternative porous to particles. The substrate shares the advantages of flat surfaces such as uniformity and suitability for surface studies and also offers a large accessible area for increased active species loading. Moreover, these materials represent a family of catalysts based on flat surfaces that are able to perform at the same level as conventional powdered catalysts. Most of flat surface catalytic materials currently described in the literature are presented as model systems that can only be used to carry fundamental studies, normally at very low pressures [18]. The fact that these VO x coated TiO2 supported nanotube arrays are able to carry out catalytic reactions under similar conditions as those used for traditional particle-based systems further advances catalytic technology. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Fabrication of TiO2 nanotubes The TiO2 nanotubes were prepared by means of an anodizing process developed by our group and previously reported [19]. This method leads to a nanotube array with a very narrow diameter and distribution which are in turn controlled by the length of the anodization time. The Ti foil (0.8mm in thickness and 99.6% in purity) and all chemicals used for the anodization process were purchased from Alfa-Aesar (Ward Hill, MA, USA) and used without further purification. Prior to anodization, the titanium foil was cleaned using distilled water and acetone in an ultrasonic bath and etched in acid solution (i.e. 3.4M HF and 5M HNO3) for 30s, rinsed with deionized water, dried in air and used immediately. During the anodizing process, the anode and cathode were exactly parallel to each other separated by a distance of 2cm. The polished Ti foil was anodized in an ethylene glycol solution containing NH4F (0.38wt%) and H2O (1.79wt%), and placed in a well-insulated bath for several hours at room temperature using a dc power supply. All anodization experiments were performed potentiostatically under constant applied voltage of 30V at room temperature. The electrochemical anodization was carried out by using a source meter (Keithley 2602, Metric Test, Hayward, CA, USA) interfaced to a computer. After completion of the anodizing process, the sample was washed with distilled water and acetone and then air dried. In order to increase the adhesion force between TiO2 nanotube layers with substrate, the prepared sample was further dried at 100°C for 30min and then sonicated for 30s in deionized water and subsequently annealed in air at a heating rate of 10°C/min to 550°C for 3h. 2.2 Vanadium oxide deposition and catalytic test Chemical vapor deposition of a vanadium oxide precursor was carried on the surface of the titania nanotube array. The surface area of the titanium substrate was 1.0cm2. For this purpose the flat surface susbtrate containing the TiO2 nanotube array was placed in a quartz microreactor and heated in helium from r.t. to 200°C at 6°C/min and then kept at 200°C for 30min; after this step vanadium (V) oxytriethoxide (Sigma-Aldrich, 95%,) was vaporized for 1h into the flowing He current (Praxair, UHP, 2.0cm3 min−1) at ambient pressure and 200°C using a microsyringe pump to deliver a total 0.06ml of vanadium(V) oxytriethoxide. After this stage a current of pure helium was flown for 0.5h to the substrate to remove residual vanadium precursor followed by an O2/He mixture (5% O2, Praxair analytical) at 400°C (6°C/min, 10.0cm3 min−1, for 2h) to decompose the precursor. Partial oxidation kinetic tests were carried at atmospheric pressure using a 5mm microreactor connected to an online GC/FID. For this purpose, the VO x -coated TiO2 nanotubes were placed on a quartz frit and held in the middle of a quartz flow reactor (0.5cm i.d.) facing the direction of flow. The samples were treated in 5% O2/He (Airgas) at 200°C, 6°C/min, 20.0cm3 min−1 , 1h before catalytic measurements. Absolute ethanol (Brampton, Ontario) was introduced into the reactor by vaporizing it into the flowing O2/He mixture at 150°C using a microsyringe pump. Reactant conversions were varied by changing the O2/He flow rate (0.3–4.1cm3 s−1) at constant ethanol partial pressures (0.23kPa) and temperature (200°C). Reactant and product concentrations were measured by gas chromatography (Shimadzu 2014 GC) using a 50m DB-5 capillary column (25m×0.53mm I.D.×1.0μm). Conversion and selectivity to products were calculated on a carbon molar basis, expressed as a mol% ratio of ethanol transformed to ethanol fed, and a ratio of ethanol transformed to each product relative to the total ethanol transformed, respectively. The rate of partial oxidation of ethanol was calculated according to Eq. (1) (1) γ ethanol = ρ F t 60 M w C ( ethanol ) where F t is the total volumetric flow (cm3 STP min−1), ρ refers to the density of ethanol (gcm−3), M w is the molecular weight of ethanol (gmol−1), and C (ethanol) is the ethanol conversion, the rates were normalized by the molar amount of vanadium present in the sample. The total carbon balance on the system was always above 98.0%. 2.3 Characterization methods The micro-structural morphology of all the TiO2 nanotube samples were examined with a field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM, Hitachi S-5000, Tokyo, Japan) equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray analyzer (EDX). The elemental compositions of the TiO2 NT samples were determined by EDX analysis. The crystallinity of the TiO2 NT samples were measured by means of X-ray diffraction (XRD) technique using a powder X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku RINT 2500, Tokyo, Japan) with Cu K radiation (λ =1.54Å) at 40kV and 50mA with a scan rate of 0.02°/s over a 2θ range of 5–90°. The materials were also characterized by DRS UV–vis (Cary 100 Bio), and Raman spectroscopy (Ranishaw, RXN1-785). The XPS analyses were carried out with a Kratos Axis Ultraspectrometer using a monochromatic Al Kα source (15mA, 14kV). Spectra have been charge corrected to the main line of the carbon 1s spectrum (adventitious carbon) set to 284.8eV. Chemical analysis of the vanadium oxide content on the nanotube array was carried out by immersing the solid substrate in a 25% H2SO4 solution and heating it to reflux temperature overnight following previously reported protocols [20,21]. The resulting solution was then analyzed colorimetrically at 450nm. These measurements were performed on a Shimadzu 3600 UV–vis–NIR spectrometer. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the TiO2 nanotubes before vanadia deposition Fig. 1(a) and (b) shows SEM images of as prepared highly ordered TiO2 nanotubes layer after anodic growth. The average tube diameter, wall thickness and tube length were 60nm, 10nm and 2μm, respectively. SEM analysis indicated that the TiO2 nanotube array is not only highly ordered but also has uniform pore size distribution offering an extremely appropriate surface for chemical vapor deposition (CVD). The XRD analysis of the as prepared TiO2 nanotubes confirmed a mixture of anatase and rutile phases (Fig. 2 ). Raman analysis on this material also confirmed this result (Fig. 3 ). 3.2 Characterization of the material after vanadium oxide incorporation Fig. 1b and d shows typical SEM micrographs obtained on the TiO2 nanotube array after vanadium oxide CVD. There are no apparent changes on the nanotube morphology when these are compared to those micrographs obtained on the TiO2 array before vanadia incorporation. EDX analysis performed in this sample indicated a total weight loading of vanadium and titanium of 0.4% and 73% respectively. By assuming a uniform anatase phase and a regular geometry for each titanium nanotube in the array with a height of 2μm and outer and inner diameters of 60 and 40nm respectively, a total available surface area of 9.9×1015 nm2 is obtained together with a surface area of 20.6m2/g. This value is in the same range as those reported for commercially available TiO2 powdered supports (8.5–50m2/g) [22]. The result of vanadium content obtained through wet chemical analysis indicated a vanadium content in the solid substrate (Ti foil+TiO2 nanotubes) of 23ppm. By assuming once again an uniform nanotube height of 2μm nanotubes and that vanadium is attached to the TiO2 nanotubes, a 0.94wt% content of V in the TiO2 phase is obtained. This value is larger than that one observed using EDX (0.4wt%) and might be explained by proposing that the EDX analysis is also probing the metallic titanium phase below the nanotube array. By using the surface area value of 20.6m2/g the values for vanadium content of 0.4% (EDX) and 0.94% (wet chemical analysis) indicate an average nominal density for vanadium between 2.0 and 5.4Vatoms/nm2 in the TiO2 nanotube surface. The X-ray diffraction diagrams obtained on these samples (Fig. 2) revealed that the crystalline anatase and rutile phases remained intact after vanadia deposition. Peaks characteristic of vanadium oxides were not observed, indicating again a good dispersion of the vanadium oxide phase. 3.2.1 Raman spectroscopy The Raman spectrum obtained on the sample after VO x deposition is shown in Fig. 3 together with the one obtained on the bare TiO2 array. Several peaks are apparent in both materials. The peaks at 400, 518 and 640cm−1 are characteristic of a titanium dioxide, composed mostly of an anatase phase. These three peaks are present in both spectra. The Raman spectra obtained for the TiO2 array after VO x deposition show additional features. First, it is clear that a segregated V2O5 phase is not present in this sample, as evidenced by the absence of the characteristic bands at 690 and 985cm−1 [23]. The broad feature in the region of 830–950cm−l observed in our sample has been previously associated with the terminal VO bonds in polyvanadate chains bonded to the support, [24] while the band at higher frequency (∼1050cm−1) is related to surface VO x species and usually assigned to vanadyl bond stretching [25] although this assignment has been questioned [26]. The peak appearing at ∼800cm−1 can be tentatively assigned to the bending and stretching of VOV moieties respectively [24,27]. This peak is characteristic of highly dispersed vanadia systems [28]. This assignment agrees with our UV–vis spectroscopy results (see below), which suggested the presence of very well dispersed VO x clusters with an average number of covalent VOV bonds of 2.6. 3.2.2 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy The XPS elemental analysis results obtained on the TiO2 nanotube material after vanadia incorporation are shown in Table 1 . The results for the fitting of the high resolution spectra for the oxygen and vanadium lines are shown in Table 2 and Fig. 4 . The surface atomic percentage of vanadium on the nanotube array as obtained by XPS is 7.3% indicating a high loading of vanadium on the nanotube surface. This yields an atomic ratio Ti/V on the surface of 2.27, while the atomic ratio of O/Vi is 8.04. By assuming that (1) the probed surface is mainly composed of oxygen, titanium and vanadium, (2) that the oxygen/titanium atomic ratio is 2 (for TiO2) and after subtracting from oxygen the contribution of chemisorbed/organic water (∼8%) the amount obtained for the oxygen associated to vanadium is 2.8 oxygen atoms per each vanadium atom. Though this number is relatively high (2.5 is the expected for a pure V2O5 phase and 2.33 for a mixed solution of V2O5 in TiO2) values above 2.5 have been previously reported and been attributed to the high chemisorption capacity of the mixed VO x /TiO2 phase [29]. The binding energy (BE) value obtained for the V 2p3/2 line was 516.1eV, which is slightly lower than the value reported in the literature for bulk vanadium (5+) oxide (516.8–517.7eV) [30]. This result is consistent with reports of BE values characteristic of highly dispersed vanadia systems [31,32]. A fitting to quantify the contributions of nominal V+5 and V+4 species was carried using a peak deconvolution routine (Fig. 4 and Table 2). Two peaks at 517.6 and 516.6eV, assigned to V5+ and to V4+ respectively [33] were used. The percentage of nominal V4+ species as calculated from XPS spectra is 43.6% of the total vanadium loading. This relatively large value is consistent with previous observations on highly dispersed vanadium oxides directly interacting with the support [34]. 3.2.3 UV–vis The information obtained through UV/vis spectroscopy on the band gap energy is extremely useful in evaluation of the dispersion and local coordination environments of supported VO x species over different substrates [35,36]. A general power law form relating the absorption coefficient with the photon energy has been suggested by Davis and Mott [37]. Though the order of this power function is determined by the type of transition involved, for the case of vanadium oxide species it seems that this choice is based mostly on the best linear fit of the energy gap curve [38–40]. By plotting this function versus the photon energy, the position of the absorption edge energy can then be determined by extrapolating the linear part of the rising curve to zero [41]. The values thus obtained carry information about the average domain size of the oxide nanoparticles since, as for the case of a particle in a box, the band gap energy decreases as the domain size increases [42]. To gain more quantitative insight on the average domain size of the species present on these samples, the UV data was evaluated using the direct allowed transition formalism in the Davis and Mott correlation. The energy gap values obtained by this method are shown in Table 3 . Here the results are compared to the value for a typical P25 supported VO x /TiO2, (1wt%) powdered sample together with values reported on some reference samples of known domain size obtained by Gao and Wachs [39]. This comparison supports the view of an extremely high dispersion for the sample obtained over the TiO2 nanotube array. Indeed, if the correlation developed by Gao and Wachs used to obtain the average number of covalent VOV bonds (CVB), a value of 2.6 is obtained, which is lower than that obtained on a typical powdered VO x /TiO2 sample at surface loadings of 1.9Vatoms/nm2 [43]. This result is in agreement with the XPS data, clearly indicating not only an extremely high dispersion of the VO x moieties in the TiO2 surface, but also a strong interaction of the vanadia species with the support. 3.3 Catalytic activity for partial oxidation of ethanol The partial oxidation of ethanol to acetaldehyde was used to evaluate the catalytic activity of the vanadium oxide coated TiO2 nanotube array. Two blank test run were carried. One with the TiO2 nanotube sample before CVD deposition and another one using a bare titanium substrate with a layer of titanium oxide without nanotubes on it after a VO x CVD process. Both of these two samples showed no significant conversion of ethanol at the reaction temperature tested (200°C). When running the vanadia coated TiO2 nanotube array, the only products observed were acetaldehyde and ethylene, though the observed selectivity to ethylene was quite low (close to 2%) under all conditions in this study. Combustion products (CO and CO2) were not observed. The high selectivity to acetaldehyde under these conditions is another indication of the high dispersion of the VO x moieties [44,45] on the TiO2 nanotube array. Fig. 5 shows steady-state ethanol conversion and the selectivity to acetaldehyde as a function of time on stream using three different space velocities (SV), indicating that with increasing SV the conversion of ethanol decreases and that the selectivity to acetaldehyde was not affected by the space velocity. We extrapolated the measured rates to zero reactant conversion (initial partial oxidation rate) and normalized them by the total V content in the catalyst. This calculation allowed us to evaluate the intrinsic activity of the VO x coated TiO2 array and compare its catalytic activity with that of typical particle based systems reported in the literature. Fig. 6 shows this calculation, indicating a value of 0.53s−1 for the normalized initial partial oxidation rate. Table 4 shows comparable reported values available in the literature at similar reaction temperatures (T =200°C) obtained for VO x supported particle based systems. The values reported by Kilos et al. [44] and Chimentão et al. [43] were recorded as normalized initial partial oxidation rates as well. The values obtained by Lakshmi et al. [46] were reported also normalized by V the loading but recorded at steady state at ∼50% conversion and offer a lower limit for comparison on intrinsic partial oxidation activities. These values indicate that the intrinsic activity of the VO x -coated TiO2 nanotube array sample is comparable to those observed on similar particle-based systems such as TiO2-P25 Degussa [43]. The use of the nanotube TiO2 array as support allowed us to create not only an extremely well dispersed active thin layer of vanadium oxide but also a large accessible surface area for the gas phase reactants. Though the calculated surface area value is similar to that of commercially available TiO2 supports the accessibility of this area to the precursor vanadium species is larger due to the morphology of the TiO2 nanotubes which potentially offer a large accessible area along channels of 60nm in average diameter and 2μm in average length. This was confirmed by the results obtained by XRD, SEM and UV/vis which indicate that in spite of the relatively high surface loadings (7.3at.% as obtained by XPS) there are not crystalline domains of vanadia in the surface, and a large fraction of vanadium seem to be interacting with the titanium oxide surface (43% as per XPS results). This is even more relevant since it has been already established that a dramatic improvement in the catalytic activity of vanadia supported TiO2-catalysts is a function of the degree of interaction between vanadium and the support [45]. The use of the nanotube array in combination with the CVD deposition appears to be particularly suitable for this specific catalyst system as the high affinity of titanium oxide for vanadia promotes the amorphization and spreading of vanadium oxide on the surface support [8]. This high degree of interaction between the active vanadium species and the support circumvents the drawbacks observed on other nanoengineered systems where weak metal or metal oxide-support interaction leads to segregation and sintering of active catalytic species and loss in activity [47]. Moreover, this affinity of vanadia for the TiO2 surface also ensures that the formation of isolated vanadium domains which can cause a blockage of the nanotube opening and a decrease of the contact surface area does not take place. 4 Conclusions We have demonstrated that using chemical vapor deposition in combination with a highly ordered TiO2 nanotube array is a novel approach to highly disperse vanadium oxides. This nanoengineered catalyst enabled us to maximize the availability of the vanadium oxide active sites to the gaseous phase. The performance of this material can be explained by the high degree of dispersion of the vanadium oxide phase due to strong interaction with the support and the available surface area the nanotube array offers. The strong interaction is guaranteed by the careful deposition on vanadia through the CVD process. This novel methodology could play a particular role on the design of new and highly efficient nanoengineered systems in heterogeneous catalysis. coredata.dc:description: A new class of nanoengineered partial oxidation catalyst has been prepared through the use of chemical vapor deposition of a vanadium oxide precursor over a highly ordered TiO2 nanotube array. A battery of characterization techniques including X-ray diffraction (XRD) together with scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Raman, and DRS-UV/vis indicate that the vanadia species are extremely well dispersed onto the surface of the nanotube array. Studies of the catalytic activity of this material were performed using the partial oxidation of ethanol as a probe reaction and compared with those obtained using typical P-25 TiO2 powdered support. Results showed that the nanoengineered approach to catalyst fabrication leads to a highly active catalytic material where most of the vanadium oxide phase is located on the surface and accessible for catalysis.
coredata.dc:title: A novel nanoengineered VO x catalyst supported on highly ordered TiO2 nanotube arrays for partial oxidation reactions
